posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Is this a comparison of swerve and tank drive or just proof that it’s possible to damage a carpet?

EDIT: is there another picture showing the impact of a current limit?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Nah, just a particularly obvious piece of 6WD field damage.  This happened in a match, not a controlled experiment.

A properly-set current limit on a tank drive makes it very difficult for that tank drive to spin its wheels, though, so it’s hard to imagine this was done with one in place.

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked:
We cant tell what the refs saw, but it is clear that the head ref was invested in the situation, occasionally leaning down towards the floor.

The red robot seemed to have lost connection (pretty sure the light should be orange for estop) at 41 seconds left, judging the alliance station’s light was blinking.

I dont think the blue robot was ever punished, but would damage to arena be a valid reason if they were?

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: How would limiting power increase performance?

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

A properly-set current limit on a tank drive makes it very difficult for that tank drive to spin its wheels, though, so it’s hard to imagine this was done with one in place.

When your wheels are spinning, it means you have no traction, so you dont move. Limiting the power of the motors mean your wheels will spin at a reduced speed, gaining traction by being in contact with the carpet, and when you have traction, you have torque. If your robot has more torque than the other, you win the pushing match.

posts.name: rocpe
posts.cooked: Noooooooo! Please Noooooooo!

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
You lose a lot of performance once your wheels slip, and it takes a given amount of torque (different for each robot, depends on weight and CoF of the wheels) to slip your wheels. Motor winding current is closely linearly correlated to output torque, so setting an output current limit a little under what’s required to spin your wheels keeps you right at the limit. Any extra power given to the motors would just be wasted slipping the wheels.

This is generally a little more effective for tank/skid steer/whatever you call it than swerve (due to what happens when weight shifts forward/backward), but it’s still a good idea for both.

posts.name: alst
posts.cooked:
Aaron_Li:

The red robot seemed to have lost connection (pretty sure the light should be orange for estop) at 41 seconds left, judging the alliance station’s light was blinking.

That’s a different robot. 1954 is the red robot in question, and they were in red 3 in that match , which is closest to the camera. It looks to me like their stack light was solid for the whole match. 1937 (red 1) is the robot that lost connection.
